content: Oh well. Btw, the Canadian Air Force is no longer called the RCAF; the RCAF, the RCN and the Canadian Army were all merged in 1968 into the Canadian Armed Forces(CAF, later shortened to just the Canadian Forces/CF)during the time of Prime Minister Pearson, as another way of pandering to the Francophones in Canada like the Quebecois who couldn't stand all these British monarchist titles or references in the Canadian military. Thus, the official name of the Air Force here is called Canadian Forces Air Command or Aircom, although the term "Air Force" is thrown around in unofficial use. The other services though, like the Navy/CF Maritime Command/Marcom have kept monarchist traditions like preceding ship's names with the "HMCS" title or "Her Majesty's Canadian Ship". quote: F-22 taxiway collision causes $1 million damage By Stephen Trimble A US Air Force Lockheed Martin F-22A Raptor has sustained more than $1 million in damage after colliding with another aircraft parked on a taxiway. A spokesman at Tyndall AFB, Florida, where the incident last week occurred, confirmed the F-22A struck a Canada's Air Force Boeing CF-18. Despite a $1 million repair bill, the collision was a relatively minor, low-speed event, the spokesman says. Details of the damage are being withheld pending the results of a safety investigation. The USAF defines a Class A safety mishap... Meanwhile, the RCAF has also dispatched a safety investigation team to Tyndall, says a spokesman for the 1st Canadian Air Division. (...) ++http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/04/17/325325/f-22-taxiway-collision-causes-1-million-damage.html
quote: F-22 taxiway collision causes $1 million damage By Stephen Trimble A US Air Force Lockheed Martin F-22A Raptor has sustained more than $1 million in damage after colliding with another aircraft parked on a taxiway. A spokesman at Tyndall AFB, Florida, where the incident last week occurred, confirmed the F-22A struck a Canada's Air Force Boeing CF-18. Despite a $1 million repair bill, the collision was a relatively minor, low-speed event, the spokesman says. Details of the damage are being withheld pending the results of a safety investigation. The USAF defines a Class A safety mishap... Meanwhile, the RCAF has also dispatched a safety investigation team to Tyndall, says a spokesman for the 1st Canadian Air Division. (...) ++http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/04/17/325325/f-22-taxiway-collision-causes-1-million-damage.html
reply: Oh well. Btw, the Canadian Air Force is no longer called the RCAF; the RCAF, the RCN and the Canadian Army were all merged in 1968 into the Canadian Armed Forces(CAF, later shortened to just the Canadian Forces/CF)during the time of Prime Minister Pearson, as another way of pandering to the Francophones in Canada like the Quebecois who couldn't stand all these British monarchist titles or references in the Canadian military. Thus, the official name of the Air Force here is called Canadian Forces Air Command or Aircom, although the term "Air Force" is thrown around in unofficial use. The other services though, like the Navy/CF Maritime Command/Marcom have kept monarchist traditions like preceding ship's names with the "HMCS" title or "Her Majesty's Canadian Ship".
title: F22 collides with parked Canadian CF18

content: certainly not the best way to make the case for more F-22s They need to redefine what constitutes a class A since most class A means the A/C is totalled. a million bucks in damage on a F-22 is similar to a small crack on the bumper cover of a Corvette
reply: certainly not the best way to make the case for more F-22s They need to redefine what constitutes a class A since most class A means the A/C is totalled. a million bucks in damage on a F-22 is similar to a small crack on the bumper cover of a Corvette

Btw, the Canadian Air Force is no longer called the RCAF; the RCAF, the RCN and the Canadian Army were all merged in 1968 into the Canadian Armed Forces(CAF, later shortened to just the Canadian Forces/CF)during the time of Prime Minister Pearson, as another way of pandering to the Francophones in Canada like the Quebecois who couldn't stand all these British monarchist titles or references in the Canadian military. Thus, the official name of the Air Force here is called Canadian Forces Air Command or Aircom, although the term "Air Force" is thrown around in unofficial use. The other services though, like the Navy/CF Maritime Command/Marcom have kept monarchist traditions like preceding ship's names with the "HMCS" title or "Her Majesty's Canadian Ship". quote: F-22 taxiway collision causes $1 million damage By Stephen Trimble A US Air Force Lockheed Martin F-22A Raptor has sustained more than $1 million in damage after colliding with another aircraft parked on a taxiway. A spokesman at Tyndall AFB, Florida, where the incident last week occurred, confirmed the F-22A struck a Canada's Air Force Boeing CF-18. Despite a $1 million repair bill, the collision was a relatively minor, low-speed event, the spokesman says. Details of the damage are being withheld pending the results of a safety investigation. The USAF defines a Class A safety mishap... Meanwhile, the RCAF has also dispatched a safety investigation team to Tyndall, says a spokesman for the 1st Canadian Air Division. (...) ++http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/04/17/325325/f-22-taxiway-collision-causes-1-million-damage.html MacDonnell Douglas was still MacDonnell Douglas when it built the CF-18's. When you say Boeing we think of the three 'lucky elephants' we bought for a billion apiece - the Boeing CF-17. And there would have been hell to pay if the 22 had rammed one of them. As it is, we have lots of CF-18's, so no big whoop.

reply: MacDonnell Douglas was still MacDonnell Douglas when it built the CF-18's. When you say Boeing we think of the three 'lucky elephants' we bought for a billion apiece - the Boeing CF-17. And there would have been hell to pay if the 22 had rammed one of them. As it is, we have lots of CF-18's, so no big whoop.
title: F22 collides with parked Canadian CF18

content: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: quote: Originally posted by Canuck_Centaur: Oh well. Btw, the Canadian Air Force is no longer called the RCAF; the RCAF, the RCN and the Canadian Army were all merged in 1968 into the Canadian Armed Forces(CAF, later shortened to just the Canadian Forces/CF)during the time of Prime Minister Pearson, as another way of pandering to the Francophones in Canada like the Quebecois who couldn't stand all these British monarchist titles or references in the Canadian military. Thus, the official name of the Air Force here is called Canadian Forces Air Command or Aircom, although the term "Air Force" is thrown around in unofficial use. The other services though, like the Navy/CF Maritime Command/Marcom have kept monarchist traditions like preceding ship's names with the "HMCS" title or "Her Majesty's Canadian Ship". quote: F-22 taxiway collision causes $1 million damage By Stephen Trimble A US Air Force Lockheed Martin F-22A Raptor has sustained more than $1 million in damage after colliding with another aircraft parked on a taxiway. A spokesman at Tyndall AFB, Florida, where the incident last week occurred, confirmed the F-22A struck a Canada's Air Force Boeing CF-18. Despite a $1 million repair bill, the collision was a relatively minor, low-speed event, the spokesman says. Details of the damage are being withheld pending the results of a safety investigation. The USAF defines a Class A safety mishap... Meanwhile, the RCAF has also dispatched a safety investigation team to Tyndall, says a spokesman for the 1st Canadian Air Division. (...) ++http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/04/17/325325/f-22-taxiway-collision-causes-1-million-damage.html MacDonnell Douglas was still MacDonnell Douglas when it built the CF-18's. When you say Boeing we think of the three 'lucky elephants' we bought for a billion apiece - the Boeing CF-17. And there would have been hell to pay if the 22 had rammed one of them. As it is, we have lots of CF-18's, so no big whoop. When Boeing bought out Douglas from McDonnell, they renamed everything to Boeing, like the MD-95 became the Boeing 717... Boeing bought Douglas for one thing, the C-17... I was working there when the "buy" took place... Boeing management took over and attitudes changed... No one who was a union member was considered a "professional", only salaried personnel and a general harassment of union personnel took place and as far as I know from those that I keep in touch with, is still going on... It has turned, sadly, into an adversarial relationship... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 This message has been edited. Last edited by: SUNLINER81, Sun 19 April 2009 06:43 PM

reply: When Boeing bought out Douglas from McDonnell, they renamed everything to Boeing, like the MD-95 became the Boeing 717... Boeing bought Douglas for one thing, the C-17... I was working there when the "buy" took place... Boeing management took over and attitudes changed... No one who was a union member was considered a "professional", only salaried personnel and a general harassment of union personnel took place and as far as I know from those that I keep in touch with, is still going on... It has turned, sadly, into an adversarial relationship... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 This message has been edited. Last edited by: SUNLINER81, Sun 19 April 2009 06:43 PM
title: F22 collides with parked Canadian CF18

content: When they did that they also closed a number of MD production facilities up here. Boeing never had much of a Canadian 'presence', so they've inherited a large operation in Winnipeg and a smaller one in Quebec. Boeing currently employs 1600 Canadians, that's down from MD's close to 10 000 in the heydays.
reply: When they did that they also closed a number of MD production facilities up here.
